div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The L massol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus, ot to the Manager, "Egyptian Gazette" Alexandria. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello." The climate of Cyprus is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook &Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: DISCONTENT IN GERMANY.
div.p: "The author, Herr Nissen-Meyer, tired lieutenant-colonel of the German Army," says the New York "Nation," who for three commanded a detachment detailed for duty in China. Having returned from this foreign service, he has written a pessi nistin, although not wholly unpatriotic, eriticism his rative country and its people. He sees signs of deterioration in society, in the army, and the body politic. But he observes: Only whoever knows his faults can correct them. Two things, however, have impressed him favourably: one is the order which prevails in public life, and the other, the military way in which officials of all kinds impart information. Often politeness is wanting, but this is a matter of minor importance

"He laments chiefly the number of rest and discontented persons who he has met in all stations of life, but particularly among the working people. The Germans are neat, class, and thrifty, but the party of the Extreme Left, the Social Democrats, is larger than in any other country in the world, being five times as great ad in England and nearly twice as great France

"Col. Nissen Meyer does not attribute this discontent to economic conditions. In Germany he finds a strong and bitter feeling of clas against clase-jealousy which takes the trouble to conceal. Even the well to do are dissatisfied, and a large number of them have cast their lot with the Social Demo erney. How many are there asks the authors, who think a do, bat willing to express their opinions openly! Many things prove that the number of malcontents is by no means insignificant," For the depression of feeling is manifested not only in the demeanour and conversation of the people, but in the sinister tone of the press The condition will probably become worse as time goes on, and Col. Nissen Meyer fears that in contemporary Germany there are elements resembling those which wrought the disintegration of the old regime in Prussia The cases of the evils which he has served he finds partly in the character of the German people, and partly in the system under which they live. For one who boasts that his point of view in cosmopolitan and impartial, he here shows himself strangely got of the transplanted German the world over. For he toes the source of these defects to the mixture f German with foreign blood, and to the contact of Germans with alien races. This conclusion has been reached apparently in order to justify the author's bitter dislike of the German colonial system. The colonies have been badly administered, and are hated at home; so that Germans prefer to put them selves under a foreign fag when they emigrate Yet the effects of foreign infoce spon Ger mans he declares to be bed; they become ostentations and are given to strong drink This is rather surprising information to Ame riosas Their observation is certainly different"

div.head: Quarantine
div.p: "A telegram received last night reports that the quarantine in the ports of Greece against arrivals from Egypt has been reduced to 48 hours

div.head: Saint Andrews Church.
div.p: The service in the above church and Seamen's Home will be conducted by the Rev. Hugh. P. Reid The hours of service will be as usual.

div.head: Sale of a Contemporary.
div.p: It is reported that the proprietor of "La Bourse Egyptienne" has sold his journal to a Belgian syndicate. The new proprietors will take over the paper from the beginning of 1908.

div.head: A Mad Dog.
div.p: A mad dog bit four persons at Exbet-El- Hagar, and then ran off to Farsko, where the police killed it with stones. Those who were bitten have been sent to Kasr el Aini Hospital for treatment.

div.head: Railway Accident
div.p: A goods train running from Marg to Cairo on Thursday ran over a native who was crossing: the line at Meushieh-station, cutting off both his legs. The man was transported to the hospital, where he expired a few minutes after arrival.

div.head: The Brindial Mail
div.p: The mail for Europe via Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G. P. O.. Alexandria, ati 3 10 p.m. on Monday for ordinary correspondence, 2. 10 p.m. for registered correspondence, midday for money orders and insured articles and at noon on Sunday for parcels.

div.head: Bull Fighting.
div.p: A London contemporary gives publications to a rumour that permission has been of the Ministry of the Interior to introduce bull-fighting into Alexandria. While placing no credence in the report, we express our hope that no such permission will ever be granted in this country.

div.head: Windsor Hotel
div.p: The Windsor Hotel continues to attract a considerable crowd nightly to its ses front age, where the excellent Rivière orchestra plays every evening until midnight. The programmes given by this band are most varied and well chosen and each of the five players is a musician of the first clam

div.head: Collision on the Nile.
div.p: A barge, loaded with stones, collided with one of the Kasr el Nil Bridge piers at an early hour on Friday morning and sank almost immediately. The crew were saved, but a native woman has disappeared and up to time of writing the body had not been recovered.

div.head: Ship Ashore in Canal
div.p: Our Suez correspondent reports, under the date of yesterday, that the homeward bound German steamer "Hagen," went ashore in the Suez Canal near station kilo 152, early that afternoon, and was blocking the traffic. She was, however, expected to be refloated at high tide the same evening.

div.head: Captain Spelterin
div.p: The "Petit Journal'' gives an interesting account of the work of the Swiss seronaut Spelterini who, it will be remembered, gave interesting lectures at Cairo and Alexandria last season on his way and intrepid excursions, with most interesting photographs of Egypt taken by him from balloons. During his latest ascent, in which he traversed the Alps for the 50th time, he took some cinemetrograph views of the passing panorama. These have been shown in the usual way and are pronounced to be the most striking that have yet been exhibited. Except for a slight deviation from a rigid position occasioned by the baloon's movement, one has positively the effect of travelling over the landscape. The views were taken from an altitude of four kilometres and are the first attempted in the service of the cinematograph.

div.head: A Revengeful Lover
div.p: Yesterday evening a quarrel, the result of the desertion of a Frenchman by his fiancée, occurred in the Rae Averoff, and became serious that revolvers were drawn and had it not been for the speedy and effective intervention of the police we would probably have had to report a case of murder. We have frequently had occasion to criticize "nos bons chaouicher" and are the couple to bear testimony to the promptness with which they acted in this instance. A Preich complex recently came from Marseilles together and an engagement ensued, but the lady evidently grew tired of her lover and turned her attention to an Italian. The jealousy of the rejected lover soon reached the pitch of vengeance and when he approached the couple in Rue Averoff yesterday evening murder was written in his eyes. The quarrel was at first confined to words and the quondam lover tried to per nade the woman to return to him, first by entreaty and then by threats. The Italian took up the quarrel and, seized with anger, the Frenchman drew his revolver, but was prevented from shooting by the policeman, who conducted all concerned to the caracol, from where the Consuls of the parties were requested to enquire into the case

div.head: NO DIVISIONS OF SUDAN ARMY COMMAND.
div.p: LONDON, Saturday. The "Times" is able to announce that there is no foundation for the rumours as to the pending resignation of Sir Reginal Win- gate and Slatin Pasha, or that the offices of the governorship of the Sadan Army Command are to be divided.

div.head: THE SIRDAR'S SCOTTISH HOME
div.p: The Sirdar has for a number of years taken his summer holiday at Dunbar, a quiet little golfing town on the east coast of Scotland. Sir Reginald has been in the habit of renting a mansion called Stafford House which overlooks the Dunbar Harbour. It is now his in- tention to build a residence of his own and for this purpose he has selected an eminence known as Knock-In-Hair. This hill stands about half a mile distant from Dunbar and commands an immense view of the Firth of Forth, the German Ocean and the Counties of Fife, Berwick and Haddington. The house when completed should be a commanding object in the district. The spot is a historical one. It was a signal station at the time of Napoleon's threatened invasion, and was also at one time said to have served the purposes of a windmill. The tower derived its name from the strange circumstances that women used to congregate around it, when watch-fires were kindled within its dome, and as they witnessed the wreck of fishing boats containing their breadwinners they dashed their heads against its walls

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: We learn with regret of the death of Lady Antoniadis, widow of the late Sir John Antoniadis, which occurred at Paris, on Thursday morning. The deceased was aged 70 years. The news of her death has been received with much regret in this town, where Lady Antoniadis was well known, and esteemed, both for her charity and amiable disposition. We offer our sincere condolences to the many relatives in their loss.

div.head: CAIRO SUBURBAN PLOTS
div.p: The Harem of the Ghezireh Palace is being demolished with a view to the construction of the new road which will lead from Ghezireh to the proposed new bridge across the river.

The works in question point to an improvement in property values on the Island of Ghezireh and there is every reason to hope that the news we announce will give a fillip to the present stagnancy in town and suburban plot. It is worthy of note that the Anglo-Belgian Company have made rapid strides in the completion of their building at Ghezireh, designed for residential flats and, although the work can hardly be completed before the early months of next year, yet the Company have already made contracts with Government officials and private parties for the flats available It is noticeable that the Anglo-Belgian Company are the first to build on the Ghezireh Estate and it is to be hoped that their enterprise will be rewarded by the success it merits.

div.head:
BOURSE AND BANKING.
BOURSE AND BANKING.
div.p: Nous avons publié hier quelques observations sur l'assemblée de la Bourse and Banking. Voici d'autres détails intéressants que nous empruntons à un confrère:
An baresa: M. Maroni remplaçant M. Eugène Nahman absent, M. Foalde secrétaire directeur, M. 8. V. Filus et Me Devonshire, avocat conseil de la Société.
M. le président déclare que l'assemblée est valablement constituée puisque 48,010 actions sont présentes ou représentées.

Une discussion s'engage aussitôt au sujet de ce qui s'est passé entre MM. Jacques et Albert Arditi et le Conseil d'administration. Finalement Me Devonshire intervient et fait observer que toutes ces discussions sont superflues et qu'il est inutile de s'y attarder; il s'agit de savoir aujourd'hui si, oui ou non, Société doit être mise en liquidation. Le président prévient l'Assemblée de gravité de la situation
Au cas où l'assemblée voudrait se réunir à nouveau, il la prie de le faire sous son entière responsabilité

Sar la demande de plusieurs actionnaires, Me la Pommeraye et Me Mercinier rédigent un ordre du jour que l'assemblée générale approuve l'unanimité, convoquant à huitaine les actionnaires et les membres du Conseil d'administration nommés par les Statuts: ceux des membres du Conseil qui ne répondront pas à cette convocation seront tenus de justifier leur absence.

Le bilan, arrêté à la date du 6 août et qui a été communiqué à l'assemblée, fait ressortir un solde en caisse de LE 184 et 599 mill. la valeur des terrains appartenant à la Société est représentée par 4,893 LE, le compte des débiteurs divers de la Société par LE 211.092, la valeur des titres en portefeuille aux cours du 6 août par LE 20,254, celle de l'agencement par LE 1.115 et enfin les pertes se soldent par LE 42,580 et 489 mill

div.head: WOMAN COMMITS SUICIDE
div.p: A fire broke out yesterday morning at the Marina, at five minutes to ten, the scene of which was a private house belonging to native. On the arrival of the brigade within four minutes of the call, the men found the wife of the owner lying in the gutter, she having in a state of uncontrollable panic, thrown herself from the roof. The woman was in a dying condition and was taken charge of by the police for transfer to hospital. The police had considerable difficulty in holding back the surging mob, which swelled in proportions as every moment passed, and threatened to greatly handicap the firemen in their work of fighting the flames, but the police did their work splendidly and put forward every effort to assist Superintendent Waller and his gallant band of fire-fighters.

The brigade found on their arrival that the fire had assumed such serious proportions, owing to the flames having been greatly aided by the fresh breeze which was prevailing and apparently by the dryness of the lath and plaster of which the building was chiefly composed, that two steamers were summoned from other stations to assist the plant taken from Menshieh. Difficulty faced the fire-brigade in another direction, the nearest hydrant being about 2,000 feet from the scene of the conflagration. The Alexandria Fire Brigade, however, is accustomed to overcoming such difficulties with a smartness which has characterised it now for many years, and they got to work in an incredibly short space of time. After the brigade had been playing on the fire for about a quarter of an hour, one of the firemen who was working inside the burning building dis- covered the body of an infant lying on the floor of one of the rooms. The poor mite had been badly burnt and presented a ghastly sight; it was beyond help, and the fireman, whose duty forbids him to be troubled by the thought of a helpless babe left to the mercy of the devouring flames by a panic-stricken mother, snatched it up in his arms and handed it over to those in charge.

Two of the rooms were totally destroyed, the fire penetrating from one storey to the other. Another room was badly damaged, and the passage of the floor in which the fire originated was also destroyed, but the scientific manner in which the fire was fought kept the flames from spreading to other rooms opening upon it. The damages have not yet been estimated.

div.head: FIRE IN CAIRO.
div.p: A fire broke out soon after nine o'clock on Thursday night in the Gamaliel District, Khan Khalil, Cairo. Fortunately the alarm was promptly given and as the ordinarily congested traffic in the Mousky was suspended the brigade lost very little time in getting to the scene of the conflagration.

On the arrival of the firemen on the spot the paper store, where the fire originated, was well alight. The efforts of the brigade were directed to the limiting of the fire. Their efforts were attended with every success and the spread of the fire was efficiently checked and the area restricted, as well as a large quantity of the shop salvaged. The damage is estimated at £300 uninsured. The cause of the outbreak is unknown.

div.head: THE CONQUEST OF MOROCCO. AMERICAN OPINION.
div.p: A German semi-official journalistic organ admits that Germany cannot oppose the pacification of Morocco by France if disorders in the Barbary States continue. The newspaper at the same time regrets that events are successively occurring in Morocco to afford France excuses for step after step of encroach- ment.

Under the terms of the Algeciras convention France and Spain are named as the executive committee of the Powers to preserve the status quo in Morocco. In consequence Germany is stopped by her own signature from objecting to French and Spanish interposition at a time when lives of Europeans have been taken in a Moorish city and when a holy war against Christians is being preached throughout the sultanate.

Nor can Germany at this time well oppose herself to the will of Europe and the obvious destiny of the whole Mediterranean coast of Africa. That coast separated from Europe by a ses which bears ships in multitude, is parted from the rest of Africa by the waste of the Sahars. In other words, Egypt and the Barbary States are related to Europe and not to Africa. They were as truly in the pale of the ancient Mediterranean civilization as were Italy and Hellas. Their historical separation from Europe in the middle age was accomplished by an Asistie, not by an African influence-the invasion from Arabia

England shrank at first from her task in Egypt, just as Prance has been hindered from finally putting her hand to the plough in Morocco But Egypt by the force of events is as finally British as is India, just as to tomorrow, the better portion of Morocco is likely to become finally French.

England is in Egypt to-day and may be in Syria tomorrow. France is in Algiers and Tunis, and will be in Morocco. Tripoli is fated to become Italian. Thus will the fertile southern shores of the Mediterranean, that once knew Greek Alexandria, Semitic Carthage, and and Roman Utios, be again wholly restored to civilization and commerce. Prom the "Chicago Inter-Ocean."

div.head: SITUATION MORE SERIOUS
div.p: The position of the "Olivemore" is more serious than yesterday and the chances of her being saved appear to decrease almost every hour, while up to the time of going to press the salvage steamer "Berger Wilhelm had not been sighted. She is hardly expected to arrive before this evening.

div.head: COLLAPSE OF A HOUSE. CHILD DIES FROM INJURIES.
div.p: Yet another report is at hand of the collapse of a house, to which a human being has fallen a victim. Shortly before noon on Thursday a loud crash aroused those in the neighbourhood of Sharia Nil, Karmous, and rushing from their houses the people saw a huge cloud of dust. On reaching the scene, the debris of a fallen house met the eye, and the fire-brigade was immediately called to the rescue of those lying buried beneath the ruins. On their arrival they discovered that two men, a woman, and a child had been buried, and setting to work they quickly recovered the child, while the others were all rescued within an hour, the last to be extricated being the woman. The two men had escaped with slight injuries, only having been held down by the weight of the material, but both woman and child were suffering badly from shock and severe contusions. The latter two were conveyed to hospital, where the child has since died. The woman is progressing favourably.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: ENGLISH AND IRISH.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "BOTPTIAN GAZETTE Sir-
To your many readers an interesting item in yesterday's issue is that re Haji A. Browne, whom you remark was "an Irishman and the only Englishman who ever saw" etc.

Ya salaam ya sidi! How can an Irishman. be an Englishman ? He is too often referred to as the latter by English papers when he, the Irishman, proves himself an interesting and worthy character. On the contrary an Irish- man is never an Englishman when he raises a dust and kicks the stars out of the heavens! All English papers have of late carefully Avoided referring to "loyal Belfast" as even British (Tho' it is not). That city of diversions and bloody ructions is pro. tem most severely Irish as it should be.

John Bull should know an Irishman is always an Irishman, whether wrong or right and should be so alluded to, and would prefer being termed a South Sea Islander rather than a mere Englishman, because the former would be noticed as a possible error and the latter too often adds stolen glory to already famous John Bull while deducting it from the ever woeful descendants of the gallant warrior Red Branch Knights of Erin.

It's a distinctly unpardonable error to call an Irishman an Englishman; it's the reverse of compliment. The most ignorant Patrick Murphy is proud of his ancient country, race, language, peculiar features (if he has any 1) larger head, harder cranium, inherited ideas, mentality and literature, and never, no never forgets,
"That Ireland was Ireland"
When England was pup"
Which is literally true except the "pup" which happens to be a Celtic poetic allusion to England's comparative juvenility.

It was the old fashioned square-headed Englishmen who best understood the Celts and in justice invented "Great Britain and Ireland," this wee word "AND" should ever be in large capitals for the benefit of modern Englishmen, as Irishmen, historically and every- way, are not even Britishers

The true Scot, tho' of pure Irish descent has fairer treatment, he is seldom called English and often gets this full benefit of his birth- place which he acknowledges with a Caledonian grant and does not dislike. He won't say he likes it, as he is cautious, which is extraordinary since his Celtic forefathers and present cousins are famed for reckless indiscretion.
Anyway, Mr. Editor, please do give Irishmen, loyal and disloyal, the full benefit of their ancestry and they will always feel grateful.
Shillelagh Castle
Yours faithfully C. W. A. N.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS

Among those who left yesterday for Europe by the M.M. "Orénoque" were the Princesses Hussein Kamel Pasha, Mr. Parkins, Moharrem Bey Hafes, Mr. Clarkson, Dr. Djemal, Mr. Adib Gariel, and Mr. Cesario.

div.head: PURCHASE OF S.S. "PRETORIA."
div.p: The S.S. "Pretoria '' has recently been bought by the Khedivial Mail Line and Graving Docks Co. Ltd. The alterations undertaken by the Khedivial Mail Line have been completed, and abe will leave Newcastle for Alexandria directly next week. Excellent first class accommodation has been provided,, and the refitting of the vessel has been carried out most thoroughly. We understand that the "Pretoria'' will be put on the extended line to Syria and Constantinople

The "Pretoria" formerly belonged to the Quebec S.S. Co. Ltd. and was built in 1878 by Messrs. W. Denny and Bros, Dumbarton. She has a gross tonnage of 3308, net tonnage 1984, length 350 feet, breadth 40 feet, and draught 23 feet.

div.head: GOLD IN MADAGASCAR STARTLING NEW DISCOVERIES
div.p: The following letter, addressed to the Editor of "The African World," from Tamatave, under date July 25, will be read with great interest by many of our readers:
Dear Sir,-The following are the exact facts concerning the new and startling discoveries o gold in this island, which have of late created so much excitement here.

Some time ago a prospector named Mortgage pegged out certain claims in a district north of Diego Suares, known as Adawa Rivere, a tract of land facing the island of Nossi-Be, about three days' march (by carriers) from the town and harbour of Diego Suarez

In order to pursue his work he borrowed money from a French merchant of Diego Suares, named Grignon. With his help he managed to engage 200 native "boys," and established his headquarters in Anta Rata, in the middle of his claims. The "boys' ' went out every day round the mountains, and every week they came to him with the result of their pannings. These were always in insignificant quantities, and indicated that the prospecting was doing very little good. Lately the results were a little better, the "boys" bringing many grammes of gold, most of it mixed with quartz dust
Mortgage noticed that one of the "boys' invariably had more gold than the others, and it was detrimental to follow him. He disguised himself as a carrier and did so.

After a long trip Mortgage joined the boy at nearly the top of a hill a few kilometres in length-and you may judge his surprise at finding that nearly all the mountain and the full perimetre formed a splendid goldfield!
He at once pegged twenty claims, and went back to fetch his friend Grignon. Together they fenced all the ground as much as possible, and started at once putting all the boys to work
The first week they crushed in a primitive style, and the result (after panning the dust nearly without water) was :-
1. Eight days: R. 12 kilos.
2. Eight days: R. 79.500 grammes. 3. Eight days: R. 55.
Total: 146 500 kilos of gold for less than a month's work-making in value (at 3,000 francs per kilo approximately) the amount of nearly 450,000 francs
Being satisfied with this splendid result, they stopped the exploitation, set the necessary watch, and left trustworthy people in their place.
They then returned to Diego Suares and deposited the gold at the Comptoir National d'escompte de Paris.
The are now waiting to get out engineers and machinery for more effective crushing from Prance
The Government Service of Mines have controlled the gold and published a report certifying that all details and the amounts of gold stated to have been recovered are correct
The discoveries that made may entirely change the future of the island of Mada gor

I am told that the number of claims already pegged is twenty, and that the quartz is everywhere the same as an extraordinarily rich sample which I have been shown. Further developments are anxiously w ed-Yours faithfully. EDGAR ROGER

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: Hier après-midi a eu lieu le grand bal costumé des enfants, qui a été des plus réussis. Les costumes étaient tous ravissants et originaux. Après le bal qui fut dirigé par Mr. Longhi, la direction ent la tâche difficile de la distribution des petits souvenirs qui ne manqua certes pas d'intérêt. Nous remercions la direction pour les plaisirs qu'elle offre à la jeunesse et sommes heureux de la décision prise pour l'année prochaine, d'organiser chaque semaine une fête enfantine, avec ginkana ou autres jeux des plus amusants

Le concert Beethoven sera exécuté demain matin sur la terrasse du Casino par l'excellent orchestre Bracale, composé de 50 musiciens. Le programme comprenant la et la symphonie du grand Mattre, ne manquera pas d'attirer tous les amis de l'art musical. Étant donné la finesse de cette musique, nous prions dès maintenant l'assistance d'éviter autant que possible de faire du bruit. Le concert commencera à 11 heures précises.

div.head: EGYPTIACA A PHYSICIAN'S MUMMY.
div.p: At the exhibition of Prehistoric Anthropology recently held at Strasbourg much interest was aroused by the mummy of a Greek- physician of the Roman Imperial period discovered at Akhmin in Upper Egypt, and now belonging to the collection of Dr. Forrer, the Swiss paleontologist and antiquary. The mummy, which is in perfect preservation, was that of a certain Paulos, surnamed Iatron, "the healer." The mummy had not the familiar shape of such relics, but was merely a long parallelogram; it was wrapped round in a toga clavate of fine linen, adorned with bands and circular patches of purple. The chin was bearded and around the neck was a wreath of Bowers, and a ribbon of honour was wound about the feet.

div.head: THE AGRIOPHAGES AND THE ROMANS
div.p: Classic geographers and the doyen of writers upon natural history, Pliny the Elder, all re- lated stories of certain wild tribes inhabiting the torrid wadys and plate and between the Nile and the Red Sea, whom they termed Agriophages or eaters of ferocious animals They are spoken of in the Periplus or descriptive chart, of the Red Sea, whose authorship is generally attributed to Arrian; also by the geographer Solinus, and, as stated, by Pliny. According to the first of the three authors this barbarous people dwelt in the desert between Thebes and Berenice

There is now a latin inscription in the Museum at Alexandria which confirms the statements of the classics. It records an expedition in the time of the Emperor Hadrian undertaken against these Agriophages. The commander of the Roman forces was named Sulpicius Serenes, and his exploits were a inscribed in duplicate in Latin and in Greek.

div.head: MAHAMET AND THE GODDESS OUZZA
div.p: In his address to the British Association at Leicester Mr. D.G. Hogarth M.A. referring to "Religious Survivals spoke of Mahomet of having, subsequent to the lessons of his exile at Medina, learnt, that the Semitic people could not be weaned to a perfectly spi- ritual system, and so came to terms with the primeval worship of the Arabian goddess at Meccs, but displaced her personality by retaining many expressions of her popular cult. However this may be, and to whatever deity Mr. Horgath was referring, the prophet did not mince matters as to some feminine members of the pantheon.

It is known that previous to his ers and to the writing of the Koran, the religion of the Arabs around Meces and Medina, and indeed wherever they roamed, was polytheistic and that they worshipped numerous deities of both sexes. In promulgating his monotheistic reli- gion the prophet necessarily denounced all other gods than Allah, and being anti-femin istje in his theology, though scarcely so in his domestic relations, Mahomet especially warns his followers gsinato female deities Among three anathematised in chapter 58 of the Korsa are three known as Art, Manat APO, and Manát of these Allat pagan pantheon was the feminine of Allah and Mankt was of Mini (deity) whilst Al Ours is that of Al Asia (powerful) The two Best female deities have frequently been found alluded to in ancient Arabian inscriptions, but not so Al'Ouma in any very direct manner. A Yemenite, or Himyaritie monumental text recently acquired by the Louvre however clearly mentions Al'Os The inscription dates from about AD-350 Its contents describe the consecration of a memorial to the goddess Our by her devo- tees, the dedicator of the monument and his daughter.

These Ouzza worshippers were therefore two persons who adored one of these early Arabian goddesses of whom Mahomet mid They are nothing more than names given by yourselves" "you and your ancestors, without Allah ever having bestowed on them" title of power"
JOSEPH OFFORD.

div.head: KING EDWARD'S "FIGHTING TEMERAIRE"
THE STORY OF A SPLENDID NAME
div.p: Commenting on the launch of the raire'' the "Pall Mall Gazette" says Today another of the famous names of British naval history reappears on the sea, in the second of our "improved Dreadnoughts," the name of the mighty man-of-war, that in the fine words of Raskin was "the Victory's companion in her closing strife," the eternally renowned name of Téméraire. The last British pennant will have been hauled down in the Channel before we forget what a Téméraire, "the” Traire of history, once did for England.
"She came to Nelson’s aid
Trafalgar’s brunt to bear,
And nobly sought to lead the can,
The Fighting Temeraire.”

Trafalgar's breat to And bly sought to lead the va The Fighting Time" And yet after all, Trafalgar Day is only one episode in a long attractive story. There were Téméraires before the Trafalgar veteran of the sea and have been since. The story of the Téméraire begins just a hundred and forty-eight years ago this month of August 1907. Across the Channel it goes back a hundred years earlier still. Originally borne by a French man-of-war the name before the date of its adoption by capture into our own service, was "The Wonderful Year," 1759, had been honourably known across the Channel for upward of a century. The first Téméraire to sail the sons was so named, as a fact, by the Grand Monarque himself, the name being appointed to a man-of-war of fifty- two guns, built in Holland for the French service in the year 1668, King Louis further selecting for the Téméraire, as a special and distinctive figurehead, an elaborate and gorgeous effigy of himself, sworded and spurred, wearing his celebrated "lion's mane" wig and a military just-au-corps tunic of cloth of gold over a scarlet vest, with crimson breeches and crimson stockings-the orthodox "get up" of a French ses officer of the times of Tourville and Jean Bart. Three other French Ténéraires followed, and then came a change of flags for the last of them. Boscawen, "Old Dreadnought" won our first Téméraire for us at the cannon's math, in the course of his battle in Lagos Bay in August, 1759.
The year 50 was the bravest then going. When an English invasion was all the world's talk, But La Cine in the straits was well banged up by Bo And Conflans ran on a lee-shore by Bold Hawke.

So our ancestors used to think, and the lower deck on board ship, too, in the days when Nelson was a boy at school. Boscawen's prize was a brand new seventy-four, and she rendered King George useful for exactly a quarter of a century.

div.head: A FAST-SAILING BEAUTY.
div.p: The Trafalgar Téméraire was the second man-of-war of ours to bear the name-a British- built 98 gun three-decker, and a fast sailing beauty, built of Essex heart-of-cak from Hainault forest, and put together at Chatham dockyard hard by, where the Victory in an earlier day had had her beginning. There can be no need to tell Englishmen what the T- méraire did at Trafalgar, nor, indeed, what became of her in the end, in the year after Queen Victoria came to the throne. Turner and the National Gallery will answer for that. We ourselves, in our modern armour-elad fleet, have already had one Téméraire, the third British warship of the name. Hardly another ship of our modern fleet, take it all in all, went through more interesting times than did Queen Victoria's Téméraire.
Here, as briefly as may be, is an outline of that battleship's career from first to last.

First commissioned in August, 1877, by Captain (as he was then) Sir Michael Culme Seymour, the Téméraire at the end of the year went out to join the Mediterranean Fleet. It was at the time of the Russo-Turkish war, and very shortly after the Téméraire had joined the fleet news came of the Russian advance on Constantinople. To prevent an attack on the Turkish capital, orders were sent to Sir Geoffrey Homby, then Commander-in-Chief, in the Mediterranean, to pass the Dardanelles. The Téméraire was one of the picked ships in the squadron that was sent up. It happened, how- ever, that the Sultan's "firman," or permit to pass the Turkish forts, had not arrived when the squadron started, and it was not known whether the forts would not try to bar their passage. In consequence, all went up cleared for action, with guns loaded and men at quarters. The admiral's orders were to make no hostile demonstration until the forts opened fire. In that case the fire was to be at once returned. They went up in thick and snowy weather, with half a gale of wind blowing, at a speed of eight knot "As we drew near the forts," described one who was there, "breathless silence reigned; Broken only by the dull thud, thud of the engines. At the guns stood their crews, one man ready to slip out the tompion, the others to ran the gun out, while the captain of each, gun stood lanyard, half- stretched, in hand." But, as it happened, the Turks hesitated about firing. The Téméraire and her consorts proceeded peacefully off Constantinople, and let go anchors two miles from the city. As we all know, their arrival check- mated the Russians. The British ships remained for three weeks, until the Treaty of San Stefano had been signed, after which they returned as they had come.

div.head: THE FOURTH OF HER LINE
div.p: At the bombardment of Alexandria the Té méraire was commanded by Captain H. Nichol- son. First posted at the entrance of the main channel leading to the harbour, with the In- flexible and the Penelope nearby, her orders were to attack Fort Mexs and the western defences of Alexandria. She shelled these works with her four 25-ton heavy guns until Fort Mexs, the second strongest work defending Alexandria, was practically silenced. Then she was signalled to cease firing. Two hours later the Téméraire moved eastward and joined the Inflexible in the attack on the Pharos fort. That place in turn was completely silenced again next morning, the Téméraire, together with the Inflexible, attacked Fort Morncrieff, which had during the night repaired its damages, but this fort also in turn speedily hoisted the white flag. The Téméraire's men were later on with the Naval Brigade at the battle of Tel-el-Kebir, and two years after that, in 1884, a detachment from the ship went up the Nile with the Khartoum Expedition, taking part at the battle of Abu Klen.

After further service in the Channel Squadron, and again in the Mediterranean, the Téméraire returned from her last sea-going commission in 1891, her captain being the gallant Admiral who now commands at the Nore, Sir Gerard Noel.
The Téméraire of Alexandria is still in existence, as one of the "Indus" group at Devonport, where she is working out her closing years as a floating workshop off the dockyard.
To-day's accession to King Edward's fleet will be our fourth Téméraire.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
LA SEMAINE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 6 Septembre.

La corbeille ayant été fermée lundi à l'occa sion du Labour Day, comme elle le sera lundi prochain pour le Jour de l'An Israelite, la semaine a effectivement commencé mardi avec un aspect assez animé. Les ordres de vente et d'achat afflusient, mais chacun eriant de son côté sans trouver de contreparties, il en est résulté une séance à peu près nulle, aux tran sactions clairsemées en Hooker, United et Delta Land et aux fluctuations plutôt no- minales. Avec la tendance générale à liquider du lendemain on se serait cru de retour aux mornes séances d'été. Bien que les nouvelles du debors et les derniers cours des bourses européennes n'eussent rien que de normal, on y cherchait des maisons à la mauvaise humeur du marché. Quoiqu'il en soit, les échanges vinrent plus laborieux et coûtèrent aux vendeurs de nouvelles concessions; les affaires, en quantités d'ailleurs restreintes, se limitèrent à la National Bank, Agricole, Hooker et United. Hier la tenue, loin de s'améliorer, s'est alourdie. On a traité par intermittence et en proportions minimes la National Bank, l'Agricole, la Delta Land, la Karam et l'United. Aujourd'hui enfin, le marché, qui avait ouvert déprimé, s'est affaissé graduellement jusqu'à la clôture, qui a eu lieu par le fait à un niveau encore inférieur à celui d'hier. Pea de transactions comme tous ces jours-ci et le petit nombre de celles qui ont été effectuées l'ont été au prix d'une nouvelle dépréciation. L'attitude indécise ou masquée du début de la semaine a fait place à des offres catégoriques. On ne dissimule plus son jean. C'est même au point que l'assertion d'après laquelle les baissiers profiteraient de la situation pour peser sur les cours n'est pas invraisemblable. En tous cas, ceux-ci ont la partie belle, les disponibilités faisant défaut en ce moment pour leur opposer une résistance quelconque. Si l'ensemble de la cote a fléchi, il est juste de dire que certaines valeurs ont bénéficié d'une avance, à cause de la demande suivie dont elles ont été l'objet ; toujours sans affaires importantes, bien entendu. Voici quel est le résultat de la huitaine: sur une soixantaine de valeurs insorites à la cote officielle de la Bourse d'Alexandrie, 32 sont en baisse et 9 seulement en hausse, les autres demeurant stationnaires. Parmi les fluctuations les plus sensibles, il faut signaler: en avance, la Daira et l'Auto- Transport qui gagnent 1/4 de livre aux prix respectifs de 12 3/4 et 4 1/4; et en recul, l'Agricole qui perd 3/16 à 8, la National Bank 1/4 à 20, la Béhéra 1/2 à 20, la Privilégiée Bière d'Alexandrie 9 fr. à 136, la Deferred Delta 1/2 à 8 1/2, les Nungovich Hotels 1/4 à 13 3/4, le Cheikh Fadl 5 fr. à 95, l'Urbaine 1/4 à 3 5/16, le Comptoir 7/32 l'action ancienne à 2 3/8, 3/16 la nouvelle à 27/16 et 3/8 la part de fondateur à 2 1/8, l'Union Foncière 3/16 à 4 1/2 et la part de fondateur United 1/41 3/4. La Ramleh progresse de 4 5/8 & 4 3/4, la Delta Light de 9 5/16 à 9 7/16, les Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie de 298 à 300, les Jouis- sances Faux du Caire de 200 à 203, les Mar- kets de 27 à 27/6, la Land Bank de 7 3,16 à 7 1/4 et l'Hélouan de 7/32 à 1/4. L'Alexandria Water rétrograde, au contraire, de 11 1/2 à 11 3/8, la Bière du Caire de 90 à 88 la Privilégiée et de 42 à 40 la Dividende, Obligation Crédit Foncier de 302 à 301 l'an cienne et de 255 à 254 1/2 la nouvelle, les Lots Turos de 159 à 158, la Cassa di Sconto de 42 à 39, la Banque d'Athènes de 110 1/2 à 109, la Delta Land de 1 7/8 à 1 3/4, l'Ordi nary Khedivial Mail de 21/3 à 21, l'Investment de 17/32 à 1/2, les Estates de 11/16 à 5/8, les Splendid Hôtels de 4 5/16 à 4 1/4, la Building Lands de 21/4 à 2 3/16, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 41/8 à 4 1/16, l'Aboukir de 27/6 à 27, l'Allotement de 2 1/2 à 2 3/8 l'ae tion et de 65 P.T. à 60 la part de fondateur, l'United de 3/8 à 11/32 l'action et de 2 à 1 3/4 la part de fondateur, les Ritz Hôtels de 11/16 à 5/8. Sur le reste de la côte il n'y a pas de changements à signaler. A Londres les valeurs égyptiennes restent soutenues; la Daïra bénéficie même de 1/4 de livre à 12 3/4 et la Deltalight de 1/8 19 5/8. A Paris les changements se réduisent à une perte de 3 fr. sur la Land Bank à 184, de 1 fr. sur le Crédit Foncier Egyptien à 685 et de 501 centimes sur le Crédit Franco-Egyptien à 107.50, le Canal de Suez remonte de 4500 à 4515, Consolidé Anglais revient de 82 5/8 à 81 3'4 et la Rente Française de 94.65 à 94.32. Tout ce qu'on peut donc observer sur les places dirigeantes pour excuser notre dépression locale est une suspension dans la demande et un arrêt consécutif de la hausse. Il en faudrait donc bien pour impressionner nos spéculateurs, s'il n'y avait pas à la réaction actuelle d'autre motif plus grave, à savoir la pénurie monétaire qui paralyse momentanément les transactions. Pourtant, le taux privé d'escompte par sa baisse de 1/4 de livre semblerait indiquer une détente. Le voici tombé en peu de jours de 4 7/8 4 1/8 % Ce Qui nous étonne, c'est qu'en. dépit de cette réduction à 4 1/8 %, tandis que le taux de la Banque d'Angleterre est maintenu à 4 1/2 % celle-ci n'ait pas réussi à augmenter de plus de 5/8 % a réserve qui est exactement de 50 % contre 49 3/8 vendredi dernier. Bien que cette circonstance soit faite pour surprendre, il n'en est pas moins satisfaisant de constater le maintien du taux de la Banque à 4 1/2 % alors surtout qu'on redonne pour elle l'obligation de le porter incessamment à 5% pour se défendre de l'absorption. américaine à la veille de la récolte. On a déjà dit que l'Angleterre pourrait sans trop de difficultés fournir les sommes nécessaires le végétation de la récolte cotonnière égyptienne, ainsi qu'au Brésil et à l'Argentine, qui ont à leur actif des balances commerciales favorables, mais à condition que l'Allemagne et surtout les Etats-Unis ne lai fassent pas d'appels de fonds comme l'année passée. Il est vrai que cette année on n'a pas reports en Europe les valeurs américaines a accepté autant que l'an dernier le papier financier de cette provenance, mais il est à craindre que l'Amérique à son tour n'use pes des mêmes aménagements que l'année passée pour les rentrées auxquelles elle a droit. Bref, New York est le point noir pour la plupart des financiers; aussi est-ce avec un profond soulagement que le marché de Londres en particulier a appris la nouvelle que le secrétaire du Trésor Améri cain allait effectuer chaque semaine des dépôts dans les banques du pays jusqu'à fin Sep tembre. Cette mesure a pour but de faire face aux besoins du commerce et de l'industrie pendant la saison, et cela immédiatement, afin de prévenir toute panique en Automne, lors du mouvement des récoltes. Si le pro-lait des douanes, que la loi autorise à prélever à cet effet, ne suffisait pas, on recourait au solde disponible du Trésor, qui seront chaque semaine, après l'habituel déficit de juillet. L'innovation du Gouvernement américain permettra sans doute à l'Angleterre de financer plus facilement la récolte égyptienne; en tous cas les plus gros nuages ont disparu de l'horizon. Reste à vivifier de nouveau notre marché au moyen d'un afflux de numéraire; les uns croient que le paiement de la récolte remplira ce bat; les autres estiment que le fellah continuera à immobiliser dans ses coffres ou en bijoux l'or qui rentre dans le pays, de sorte que celui-ci n'en retire aucun profit immédiat. C'est peut-être dans un juste milieu qu'il faut chercher la vérité. La récolte mettra de fortes sommes en circulation, mais insuffisantes pour rétablir complètement l'équilibre.

Est-ce à dire qu'une nouvelle débâcle soit en perspective, nous ne le croyons pas; la dépréciation actuelle des meilleurs titres est une garantie contre cette éventualité. Une hausse modérée est possible et même probable en hiver. Mais si dans la situation délicate où se trouve le pays au point de vue financier, ceux qui ont une part de responsabilité quelconque laissent se reproduire les abats de l'an dernier, qui voudrait répondre de l'avenir ! Nous espérons que les organisateurs de nouvelles sociétés et de manœuvres boursières voudront bien attendre une saison moins critique pour se livrer à leurs fructueuses mais dangereuses opérations. C'est précisément pour n'avoir pas emboité le pas aux claironneurs de hansse que nous avons été récemment taxé par un confrère de pessimisme. Non, ainsi que nous l'avons déjà écrit, nous ne vou lons pas induire le public en erreur et à la faveur d'articles réchauffés permettre à des spéculateurs en somme pen intéressants de glisser leurs paquets à l'épargne, déjà saignée à blanc, L'état réel du marché, le mouvement des transactions, les fluctuations de la cote, la tendance exacte du moment, voilà ce que le lecteur a le droit de connaltre. Nous ne comprenons pas qu'un journal sérieux puisse en matière de bourse s'occuper d'autre chose et se montrer de parti pris optimiste on pessimiste.

Le marché à terme qui a été rétabli au Caire depuis le 1er Septembre et qui, au dire de certains, devait produire un mouvement irrésistible, n'a donné lieu à aucune opération. C'est du moins ce qu'on dit. On ajoute même que dans la pénurie monétaire où se débat la spéculation, les affaires à terme sont impossibles, la confiance qui est indispensable pour ce genre de transactions faisant totalement défaut. Dans ce cas, il faudrait attendre des temps meilleurs. Cette constatation d'un fait qu'on aurait dû prévoir n'est peut-être pas étrangère à la réaction de cette semaine.

A l'assemblée d'hier de la Bourse and Banking, les actionnaires ont joui d'une nouvelle surprise. Alors qu'ils s'attendaient enfin à délibérer valablement, quel que fût le nombre des actions représentées, puisqu'il s'agissait d'une deuxième convocation, île se sont vus renvoyés à une troisième date, jeudi 12 courant. Pourvu que ce soit la dernière ! Me. Mercinier a expliqué que M. Arditi n'était pas plus coupable que les autres administrateurs, que ceux-ci cherchaient à éluder leur part de responsabilité en s'en prenant à leur collègue, qu'ils connaissaient tous l'état des affaires et qu'ils avaient eux-mêmes participé aux principales opérations, bref une série de déclarations amplement suffisantes à motiver l'intervention du parquet pour initier des poursuites contre la société en la personne de son conseil d'administration.

div.head: Coton
div.p: Le mieux dans l'activité et l'allure de marché, que nous signalions dans notre présidente revae, s'est encore accented pendant la semaine qui vient de finir; mais, chose qui paraîtra peut être surprenante à beaucoup de monde, c'est précisément la baisse à 19 13/16 qui, en tentant les acheteurs, a fait naître cette animation relative qui règne depuis trois ou quatre jours et qui, à un moment donné, & pa faire croire que la situation était définitivement changée. En tous cas, il faut bien reconnaître que le marasme dont on se plaignait n'existe plus et qu'à ce point de vue, l'amélioration est réelle. Plus on est de fous, plus on s'amuse, dit-on! Eh bien! aujourd'hui il y a bien plus de faiseurs qui ont pu s'intéresser à l'article et cela fait espérer que, pour le moins, cette cir constance pourra maintenir un peu d'entrain et qu'on aura éviter l'erreur d'exagérer les mouvements, qui, surtout dans un marché aumi restreint que celui que nous avons, pourrait être fatale. Il y a du mieux certainement, mais nous ne sommes pas sortis de l'ornière et, comme nous l'avons déjà dit, nous sommes encore loin du jour où l'on pourra dire que nous en avons fini avec les difficultés financières qui ont tout bouleversé sur notre place. C'est un point qu'il ne faut pas perdre de vue, d'autant plus que notre récolte promet d'être colossale Maintenant, voici résumé le plus justement possible l'historique de la semaine. La matinée de Samedi a été calme et quelque peu marquée du coin de la faiblesse, les affaires ayant été peu nombreuses et les prix ayant fini en baisse de 3/32. Tout le monde était sur la réserve et semblait craindre une surprise pour la reprise des affaires qui devait avoir lieu Mardi matin, tant en Amérique qui avait 2 jours de chômage à l'occasion du Labor Day de Septembre et à la suite duquel notre Association des Courtiers en Marchandises avait décrété un jour de repos chez nous pour la journée de Landi Manquant de nouvelles de New York et de New Orleans, c'est sous l'influence des faits locaux que nous avons débuté Mardi, séance qui nous a valu la bagatelle d'une baisse de 3,8 de tallari ayant pour unique cause la piètre tenue du disponible. Le lendemain, le ton a été plus encourageant et la côte a fini en reprise de 3/32, suivie hier d'une antre avance de 5/32 mais, aujourd'hui, malgré la vivacité de la lutte, l'allure a de nouveau été peu satisfaisante et c'est à peine si le cours de 30 1/8 a pu être maintenu Dans l'entre-temps, on avait fait beaucoup d'affaires et le cours maximum de la semaine avait pu être pratiqué à 20 5/16. Comme tendance, il n'y en a aucune à signa ler et comme nous l'avons déjà fait remarquer il n'y a qu'un peu plus d'affaires, et voilà tout: au fond, la demande de la part de la filature est confuse aux besoins immédiats et il est incontestable que cette tactique réservée de la consommation n'est pas faite pour favoriser la spéculation. On dira peut-être que l'exporta tion absorbe tous les arrivages, mais oublie-t- on si vile que les expéditions de l'intérieur ont à peine commencé et que les recettes promettent un développement des plus rapides à la suite de l'empressement extraordinaire que met le cultivateur dans la Haute-Egypte vouloir se défaire de son coton, en point de consentir des ventes même à crédit aux grandes maisons! Cette anxiété à vouloir vendre ne peut avoir pour cause qu'une réas site de récolte bien supérieure à ce que l'on dit. D'ici trois ou quatre jours, la Basse-Egypte aussi va commencer ses envois et comme les choses vont au mieux de ce côté-ci, il y a lieu de s'attendre à un développement rapide des recettes, circonstance qui ne peut que alourdir le marché, à moins d'ane demande formidable du dehors de nature à tenir tête à l'avalanche. Mais n'anticipons pas. Un mauvais point à signaler, c'est la tendance du report à augmenter. Chaque fois que le spéculateur est faible, il se porte sur les dates éloignées et c'est là un fait qui fait dire à beaucoup de monde que la position actuelle du marché n'est nullement solide. L'Alexandria General Produce Association vient de publier son Résumé du mois d'Août an sujet de la récolte sur pied. Certes il ne dit rien qui ne soit déjà connu du public, mais en somme il confirme les bonnes informations de l'intérieur dont nous avions donné un aperçu dans notre dernière revie Elle a aussi distribué son Bulletin annuel du mouvement de la récolte. Nous regrettons que le manque d'espace ne nous permette pas la reproduction, mais les quelques chiffres que nous allons eiter résument tout ce qui peut intéresser nos lecteurs. Les recettes ont dû être augmentées de 75000 Cantars environ et cette rectification fait monter le total de la récolte à Cantars 6,949,000, oe qui correspond, pour ainsi dire, à l'attente générale. D'autre part, les exportations se sont élevées à Cantars 6,977,000, y compris Port- Saïd et autres ports pour Balles 1813, ainsi que les retraits de nos deux filatures, qui n'ont été que de 21,000 Cantars, soit dit en passant. Quant au stock révisé au 31 Août, il est de Cantars 172,000, mais il est presque en entier vendu à la filature. L'Amérique ne nous donnera son rapport que le 9 courant. On ne connaît pas de pronostics, mais on sait déjà que Price, dans le sien, parle de 77 environ, tandis que Miss Giles met la condition de la plante à 73. Si le Bureau devait venir dans les environs de 73, ce ne serait certainement pas mal. Le seul point inquiétant c'est le retard de la récolte qui l'expose aux dégâts du froid en Octobre et première moitié Novembre.

Les avis de New York sont en général pour la hausse, mais la divergence en ce qui concerne les motifs sur lesquels on la base en rendent la sincérité douteuse. Les uns disent que la sécheresse persiste au Texas, tandis que d'autres parlent de tempêtes dans les Etats du Golfe. On dit aussi que la demande de Manchester est bonne, mais reste à savoir ce qu'il y a de vrai de cette macédoine d'informations. I Pour le moment, elles maintiennent les cours très fermes. Les arrivages en coton nouveau Haute- Egypte ont donné un peu d'animation à notre marché du disponible, mais pour ce qui est des prix pour ces provenances, il y a nécessairement de la baisse et elle s'élève à 7/8 de tallari. Pour les vieux cotons, difficiles à trouver, la cote a été maintenue au niveau de Vendredi. Les exportations à partir du ler Septembre n'ont été que de Balles 1,500, contre 1,400 en 1906 pour la même période. Pour la semaine prochaine, il y aura avantage pour l'année courante qui a une semaine de 3,700 Balles seulement comme comparaison. Liverpool n'a guère été actif pour les Egyptiens disponibles, et pour ce qui est des prix, les changements consistent en une baisse de 1/16 pour le spot qui est à 10 11/16, et en une hausse de 2/64 pour les futurs côtés à 10 33/64 le Novem-re Les Américains, par contre, ont été mieux traités comme affaires et comme cours. Ces derniers finissent ce soir à 7.51 le spot, 6.86 Octobre Novembre et 6.76 le Janvier Février, ce qui fait respectivement 2, 5 et 4 points de hausse
Graines de Coton
Pour commencer, voici les chiffres de l'année de la Produce Association:
Rectification Ard. 123.000
Total Récolte " 4.270.000
Exportation Angleterre 3.236.000 " "
Continent 555.000
Stock revisé 41.250 "
Huileries locales... 540.000 "
de l'intérieur 201.500 "

Pour cette fois on parlait pouvoir compter sur l'exactitude du chiffre du Stock. Les arrivages sont supérieurs à ceux de l'année passée, mais les besoins des exportateurs absorbent tout et maintiennent le spot à P.T. 80 1/2 pour Fayoumi et Hante-Egypte. En contrats, peu d'affaires et fluctuations continuelles à cause de l'étroitesse du marché, mais cours fermes. Maximum de la semaine PT. 71 3/4; minimum P.T. 70 3/4 et clôture P.T. 71 15/40 pour les 3 mois. Hall cote 8 pour Septembre et £7.2/6 pour Novembre Janvier. Demande peu active.

div.head: THE BEST FRIENDS OF PE-RU-NA ARE MOTHERS AND CHILDREN
PE-RU-NA SHOULD BE KEPT IN EVERY HOUSEHOLD
WHERE THERE ARE LITTLE CHILDREN
div.p: Peruna should be kept in the house all the time. Don't wait until the child is sick, then send them to a drug store. But, have Peruna on hand-accept no substitute. Children are especially liable to acute catarrh. Indeed, most of the affections of childhood are catarrh. All forms of sore throat, quinsy, throat, hoarseness, laryngitis, etc., are but different phases of catarrh. Pe-ru-na Contains No Narcotics. One reason why Peruna has found permanent use in so many homes is that it contains no narcotic of any kind. Peruna, if taken according to printed directions, is perfectly harmless. It can be used any length of time without acquiring a drug habit. It does not produce temporary results, but it is permanent in its effect. It has no bad effect upon the system, and gradually eliminates catarrh by re- moving the cause of catarrh.
Mrs. F. Brockman, 813 Meade street, Appleton, Wis., writes:

"I have never had a return of the catarrh, which had made me so miserable and unhappy before I began taking Peruna. I would not be without it in the house,now. I have a baby boy, two years old, to whom I give Peruna for a cold, and my husband also takes Peruna. I thank you and wish you well." ---Mrs. F. Brockman

div.head: NO DOCTOR REQUIRED
div.p: Mr. Edward Otto, 97 De Soto street, St. Paul, Minn., writes: "I cannot say enough for Peruna. It has done great work in my family, especially for my oldest boy. We had doctored with three or four different doctors and they did not seem to do him any good. "We gave up hopes of cure, and so did they, but we pulled him through on Peruna. We had several doctors and they said they could do no more for him, so we tried Peruna as a last resort, and that did the work. Since then we keep it in the house all the time, and no doctor is required."--Edward Otto, There are a multitude of homes where Peruna has been used off and on for twenty years. Such a thing could not be possible if Peruna contained any narcotics.

div.head: The Benefit Which the Children of the United States Have Received From Pe-ru-na Can Never Be Put Into Words
div.p: The chronic ailments it has prevented, the suffering it has mitigated, will never be fully recorded. But at least this much can be said that the coming generation owes a great debt to Peruna, for it is in the tender years of youth that slight ailments are liable to develop into lasting disease, thus blasting the whole career of the Individual. The mothers who are bringing up their children to-day to believe in Peru- na are speaking from their experience. These children brought up to believe in Peruna from the start, will, when they become heads of families them- selves, use Peruns with unquestioning faith.

div.head: A Child's Life Saved.
div.p: Mr. G. H. Farmer, New Martinsville, W. Va., writes: "Our little son, Harry, is well and healthy now and we think if we do as you directed us, he will keep his health and grow strong. "We know that our little son's life was saved by your wonderful medicine, Peruna, and we shall always praise Peruna and use it in our family when needed. "Should we have any more catarrhal trouble in our family, we shall always write to you for treatment." Mr. W. F. Doring, Mt. Vernon. Mo., writes: "I have used Peruns to my entire satisfaction and am exceedingly well pleased with the results, having suffered greatly with catarrh of the stomach."

Mrs. J. C, Sterling, 18 Brown Avenue, Norfolk, Va., writes: "My little boy, Meredith, suffered with indigestion so badly he could not eat anything without it making him very sick, so I thought (as many others have) that I would try Peruna, and 1 worked like a charm. "Now he eats anything he wishes, and I would not be without it for anything "My other little boy, Alfred, two and a half years old, has taken it and received a much benefits from Peruna sehin brother. I hope my testimonial may be of some benefit to others, as I feel as though I cannot praise it enough." Mrs. J. C. Sterling Mr. Howard Andrew Sterner, 44 Canal street, Reading, Pa., writest "I have Peruns in my house all the time and won't be without it. It is good for children when they catch a cold or croup. It cured my baby boy of croup. "I have introduced Peruns into ex families since I received your last letter, and four have seen relief already." -Howard Andrew Sterner. Pe-ra-na Protects the Entire Household As soon as the value of Peruna is appreciated by every household, both as a preventive and care, tens of thousands of lives will be saved, and hundreds of thousands of chronte, lingering casos of catarrh will be prevented.

div.head: WHEN SICKNESS COMES TO THE LITTLE ONES
IT IS THE MOTHER THAT CHIEFLY SUFFERS
div.p: She suffers even more than who happens to black. Hes sympathy is deeper than that of any other member of the family The mother looks forward with dread to the torrid heat of summer, thinking of her children and the many labis ties to disease that are before them. Spring and summer are sure to bring ailments, especially the Middle Is donos sak discover that Peruna is the best friend he has in time of illness among the children.

div.head: A MULTITUDE OF MOTHERS
div.p: Have discovered that Peruna is their stand-by, and that in many of the ailments of spring and summer to which the children are subjected, Peruss is the remedy that will generally quickly relieve. Whether it is spring fever or stomach derangement, whether it is indigestion or bowel disease, a catarrhal congestion of the mucous surfaces in the case. Peruns quickly relieve this condition of the mucous membranes. Its operation is prompt, the children do not dislike to take the medicine, it has no deleterious effects in any part of the body. It simply removes the cause of the disagreeable symptoms and re health. div.head: Alexandria General Produce Association
div.p: Section Cotonniere RÉSUMÉ DES RÉPONSES REÇUES EN AOÛT 1907 N° 177 La température en Août a été très favorable et, sous son influence, la plante cotonnière a fait de bons progrès Les conditions dans lesquelles se trouve la récolte sont telles que, d'une façon générale, la neillette semble pouvoir commencer vers le 10 Septembre. La première cueillette promet d'être très abondante. Les vers, en dehors de quelques localités sans importance, n'ont pas été signalés en Août; dans tous les cas, les dégâts qu'il ont pu faire, sont insignifiants Des brouillards ont fait leur apparition, mais, légers et de courte durée, ils n'ont pas causé de dégâts appréciables à la récolte. L'eau a été suffisante. Dans la Haute Egypte, la cueillette avance rapidement partout et les résultats, comme rendement cultural, semblent donner pleine satisfaction. Là aussi, les vers et les brouillards ont laissé la récolte indemne jusqu'ici. Pour le Comité Le Président en fonction H. BINDERNAGEL Alexandri, le 31 Août 1907.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: I L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur d'informer le Public que le livret du Tarif de transport des cotons (égrenés et pressés hydrauliquement ou à la vapeur et non égrenés) ainsi que des graines de coton, publié et appliqué la précédente campagne cotonnière (1906-1907), continue à être mis en vigueur sans modification durant la prochaine saison cotonnière (1907-1908). De plus un supplément contenant le Tarif des cotons, etc. expédiés de certaines gares qui n'étaient pas comprises dans le dit livret vient d'être imprimé à part et sera remis gratis par les gares cotonnières on l'Admi- nistration Centrale (Service des Marchandises) à toute personne qui en fera la demande.

Il est à rappeler qu'à l'avantage pour les négociants d'expédier leurs cotons non égrenés par sac se joint celui d'être dispensés de présenter des états des poids détaillés de leurs expéditions et de bénéficier d'un délai de grâce de 96 heures an lien de 48.

L Unifiée est reste inchangée à 101 La National Bank s'est maintenue à 20. L'Agricole a rétrogradé de à 8 et la Daïra de à 12. La Delta Light a été sont à

A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a perdu 3 francs à 685. La Banque d'Athènes ferme à 111 et les Lots Tures de 166. lei, la semaine s'est terminée aujourd'hui par une séance qui sans être meilleure en point de vue des prix, a été cependant plus animée Le volume des tractions à pei réelle amélioration et telles valeurs qui avaient en cours de séance fléchi plus que de maison,

Il est certain à tous égards que nous aurions eu une côte encore plus favorable s'étaient les nombreux ordres de ventes exécutés pour 1 compte des banques; mais, comme tout a one fin, il est permis d'espérer une reprise dès

As demeurant, nous assistons à un lave ment résultant de l'inactivité des affaires bien plus qu'à une baisse, et l'on peut tabler sans crainte sur une place qui, comme la nôtre, a montré tant de résistan

La réunion a débuté par une longue discussion au sujet de la légalité de la révocation de MM. Arditi, et de leur exclusion des séances du conseil d'administration,sous prétexte qu'ils étaient débiteurs envers la Société

Un nombreux groupe d'actionnaires a mandé envoi de l'assemblée à betaine que le conseil d'administration au complet donne des éclaircissements sur sa gestion. L'avocat conseil de la Société fait remar quer que la meublées été constitué afin de prononcer oui on son liquidation de la Société et le président a ajouté qu'en renvoyant la décision beit jours, on risquerait de se d'une demande en fail

En fin de compte, un cèdre de jour a d adopté, convoquant les actionnaires et hautaine mais que tous les membres du conseil d'administration nommé par les Statuts; ceux des bros de col qui ne répondront p cette convocation seront tenus de justifier lear egisted récemment à Londres une glaise pour Egypte sous le "The New Land Company of Egypt capital of 200,000, divisions of £1.

Parmi les fondateurs se trouvent MM. Ralli, H. de Pitner, Tambaco Poulo, Drossos et Protopapas

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaust ive and important reviews, of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share market, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is PT. 10 extra). For further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette”.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication la construction d'un pont provisoire en bois à établir sur le Canal Mahmoudieh.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE 50 (Cinquante)
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.

Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 17 Septembre 1907. Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour construction d'un pont provisoire en bois à établir sur le Canal Mahmoudieh."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la comptabilité générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 17 Septembre 1907 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
Le Vice-Président, (Signé) DR. SCHIERS
Alexandrie, le 2 Septembre 1907. 30863-3-2

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
